what: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Continuous Variables — calculate_smd
title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Continuous Variables — calculate_smd
text: Calculates standardized mean difference (SMD) two groups continuous variables using either Cohen's d Hedges' g. SMD key metric assessing baseline balance randomized controlled trials, particularly important GBA/AMNOG dossier submissions.

title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Continuous Variables — calculate_smd
code: calculate_smd(   mean1,   sd1,   n1,   mean2,   sd2,   n2,   method = c("cohens_d", "hedges_g"),   conf_level = 0.95 )

title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Continuous Variables — calculate_smd
text: mean1 Numeric. Mean group 1 (treatment group). sd1 Numeric. Standard deviation group 1. Must positive. n1 Integer. Sample size group 1. Must >= 2. mean2 Numeric. Mean group 2 (control/reference group). sd2 Numeric. Standard deviation group 2. Must positive. n2 Integer. Sample size group 2. Must >= 2. method Character. Method calculating SMD. One : "cohens_d" (default): Uses pooled standard deviation "hedges_g": Applies small-sample bias correction Cohen's d conf_level Numeric. Confidence level CI calculation (default: 0.95).

title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Continuous Variables — calculate_smd
text: named list components: smd: standardized mean difference ci_lower: Lower bound confidence interval ci_upper: Upper bound confidence interval method: Method used ("cohens_d" "hedges_g") se: Standard error SMD

title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Continuous Variables — calculate_smd
text: Cohen's d calculated : $$d = \frac{\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2}{s_{pooled}}$$ \(s_{pooled} = \sqrt{\frac{(n_1-1)s_1^2 + (n_2-1)s_2^2}{n_1+n_2-2}}\) Hedges' g applies correction factor small samples: $$g = d \times \left(1 - \frac{3}{4(n_1+n_2)-9}\right)$$ 95% confidence interval calculated using large-sample variance: $$Var(d) = \frac{n_1+n_2}{n_1 n_2} + \frac{d^2}{2(n_1+n_2)}$$

title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Continuous Variables — calculate_smd
text: Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical Power Analysis Behavioral Sciences (2nd ed.). Lawrence Erlbaum Associates. Hedges, L. V., & Olkin, . (1985). Statistical Methods Meta-Analysis. Academic Press.

title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Continuous Variables — calculate_smd
code: # Cohen's d for age between treatment groups calculate_smd(   mean1 = 55.2, sd1 = 12.3, n1 = 150,   mean2 = 53.8, sd2 = 11.9, n2 = 148 ) #> $smd #> [1] 0.1156738 #>  #> $ci_lower #> [1] -0.1115965 #>  #> $ci_upper #> [1] 0.342944 #>  #> $method #> [1] "cohens_d" #>  #> $se #> [1] 0.1159563 #>   # Hedges' g with small sample correction calculate_smd(   mean1 = 55.2, sd1 = 12.3, n1 = 25,   mean2 = 53.8, sd2 = 11.9, n2 = 23,   method = "hedges_g" ) #> $smd #> [1] 0.1137085 #>  #> $ci_lower #> [1] -0.4530328 #>  #> $ci_upper #> [1] 0.6804498 #>  #> $method #> [1] "hedges_g" #>  #> $se #> [1] 0.289159 #>

what: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Binary Variables — calculate_smd_binary
title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Binary Variables — calculate_smd_binary
text: Calculates standardized mean difference (SMD) two groups binary categorical variables using arcsine transformation logit method. essential assessing baseline balance categorical covariates clinical trials.

title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Binary Variables — calculate_smd_binary
code: calculate_smd_binary(   p1,   n1,   p2,   n2,   method = c("arcsine", "logit", "raw"),   conf_level = 0.95 )

title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Binary Variables — calculate_smd_binary
text: p1 Numeric. Proportion group 1 (treatment). Must 0 1. n1 Integer. Sample size group 1. Must >= 2. p2 Numeric. Proportion group 2 (control). Must 0 1. n2 Integer. Sample size group 2. Must >= 2. method Character. Method calculating SMD. One : "arcsine" (default): Uses arcsine square root transformation "logit": Uses logit transformation (log odds) "raw": Raw proportion difference standardized pooled variance conf_level Numeric. Confidence level CI (default: 0.95)

title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Binary Variables — calculate_smd_binary
text: named list components: smd: standardized mean difference ci_lower: Lower bound confidence interval ci_upper: Upper bound confidence interval method: Method used se: Standard error SMD

title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Binary Variables — calculate_smd_binary
text: Arcsine method (recommended proportions): $$SMD = 2 \times (\arcsin(\sqrt{p_1}) - \arcsin(\sqrt{p_2}))$$ transformation stabilizes variance across range proportions bounded, making suitable proportions near 0 1. Logit method (log odds ratio): Calculates log odds ratio standardizes: $$SMD = \frac{\log()}{\pi/\sqrt{3}}$$ \(= \frac{p_1/(1-p_1)}{p_2/(1-p_2)}\) Raw method: $$SMD = \frac{p_1 - p_2}{\sqrt{p(1-p)}}$$ \(p = \frac{n_1 p_1 + n_2 p_2}{n_1 + n_2}\)

title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Binary Variables — calculate_smd_binary
text: Austin, P. C. (2009). Balance diagnostics comparing distribution baseline covariates treatment groups propensity-score matched samples. Statistics Medicine, 28(25), 3083-3107.

title: Calculate Standardized Mean Difference for Binary Variables — calculate_smd_binary
code: # Compare sex distribution (60% female in treatment, 55% in control) calculate_smd_binary(p1 = 0.60, n1 = 150, p2 = 0.55, n2 = 148) #> $smd #> [1] 0.1011905 #>  #> $ci_lower #> [1] -0.1258899 #>  #> $ci_upper #> [1] 0.3282709 #>  #> $method #> [1] "arcsine" #>  #> $se #> [1] 0.1158595 #>   # Using logit transformation calculate_smd_binary(   p1 = 0.60, n1 = 150,   p2 = 0.55, n2 = 148,   method = "logit" ) #> $smd #> [1] 0.1129091 #>  #> $ci_lower #> [1] -0.1406897 #>  #> $ci_upper #> [1] 0.3665079 #>  #> $method #> [1] "logit" #>  #> $se #> [1] 0.1293895 #>

what: Calculate SMD Directly from Data — calculate_smd_from_data
title: Calculate SMD Directly from Data — calculate_smd_from_data
text: Calculates standardized mean difference variable directly data frame, automatically detecting whether variable continuous categorical.

title: Calculate SMD Directly from Data — calculate_smd_from_data
code: calculate_smd_from_data(   data,   var,   trt_var,   ref_group = NULL,   method = c("auto", "cohens_d", "hedges_g", "arcsine", "logit", "raw"),   conf_level = 0.95,   continuous_threshold = 10 )

title: Calculate SMD Directly from Data — calculate_smd_from_data
text: data data frame containing analysis data. var Character. Name variable calculate SMD . trt_var Character. Name treatment group variable. ref_group Character NULL. Value reference (control) group. NULL, uses first level treatment variable. method Character. Method SMD calculation: "cohens_d": Cohen's d continuous variables "hedges_g": Hedges' g (bias-corrected) continuous variables "arcsine": Arcsine transformation binary/categorical "logit": Logit transformation binary/categorical variables "raw": Raw proportions/means without transformation "auto" (default): Automatically selects based variable type conf_level Numeric. Confidence level CI (default: 0.95) continuous_threshold Integer. Minimum number unique values treat numeric variables continuous (default: 10). Used method = "auto".

title: Calculate SMD Directly from Data — calculate_smd_from_data
text: named list components: smd: standardized mean difference. multi-level categorical variables, returns SMD maximum absolute value, preserving sign. ci_lower: Lower bound confidence interval ci_upper: Upper bound confidence interval method: Method used var_type: Detected variable type ("continuous" "categorical") se: Standard error SMD

title: Calculate SMD Directly from Data — calculate_smd_from_data
text: method = "auto": Numeric variables > continuous_threshold unique values treated continuous (using Cohen's d) Numeric variables <= continuous_threshold unique values treated categorical Character/factor variables treated categorical (using arcsine) categorical variables 2 levels, function calculates maximum absolute SMD across pairwise level comparisons. Method-specific considerations: "logit": Useful binary variables requires boundary handling proportions 0 1 (adds 0.5/N continuity correction). Results logit scale; back-transformation straightforward. "raw": Appropriate transformation desired. Calculates SMD directly raw proportions binary variables, standardized pooled standard deviation binary variable.

title: Calculate SMD Directly from Data — calculate_smd_from_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create example data adsl <- data.frame(   AGE = c(rnorm(100, 55, 12), rnorm(100, 54, 11)),   SEX = c(sample(c("M", "F"), 100, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.4, 0.6)),           sample(c("M", "F"), 100, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.45, 0.55))),   TRT01P = rep(c("Treatment", "Placebo"), each = 100) )  # Continuous variable calculate_smd_from_data(adsl, "AGE", "TRT01P", ref_group = "Placebo")  # Categorical variable calculate_smd_from_data(adsl, "SEX", "TRT01P", ref_group = "Placebo") } # }

title: Calculates ranking probabilities and SUCRA (Surface Under Cumulative Ranking curve) or P-scores for treatments in network meta-analysis. — calculate_sucra
text: seed NULL, global random number generator state modified via set.seed(). need preserve RNG state, either set seed = NULL manage seeding externally, save/restore .Random.seed calling function.

title: Calculates ranking probabilities and SUCRA (Surface Under Cumulative Ranking curve) or P-scores for treatments in network meta-analysis. — calculate_sucra
code: # Calculate SUCRA rankings nma_data <- data.frame(   study = c("S1", "S2", "S3"),   treat1 = c("A", "B", "A"),   treat2 = c("B", "C", "C"),   effect = log(c(0.75, 0.90, 0.80)),   se = c(0.12, 0.15, 0.18) ) nma_result <- network_meta(nma_data, effect_measure = "hr") sucra <- calculate_sucra(nma_result) sucra$ranking #>   treatment mean_rank sucra prob_best prob_worst final_rank #> B         B     1.425 78.75     0.599      0.024          1 #> C         C     1.759 62.05     0.391      0.150          2 #> A         A     2.816  9.20     0.010      0.826          3 sucra$interpretation #> [1] "Treatment ranking by lower is better (SUCRA, %). Best: B (78.8%), Worst: A (9.2%)"

title: Compare Direct and Indirect Evidence — compare_direct_indirect
text: direct_result ComparisonResult list estimate se direct evidence indirect_result ComparisonResult indirect_comparison() effect_measure Character. Effect type (results) conf_level Numeric. Confidence level. Default: 0.95

title: Compare Direct and Indirect Evidence — compare_direct_indirect
text: list components: direct_estimate Direct evidence effect estimate indirect_estimate Indirect evidence effect estimate pooled_estimate Inverse-variance weighted pooled estimate pooled_ci CI pooled estimate inconsistency_p P-value inconsistency test effect_measure Effect measure used is_consistent Logical; TRUE p > 0.05

title: Compare Direct and Indirect Evidence — compare_direct_indirect
code: # Compare direct and indirect evidence # Direct evidence: A vs B from head-to-head trial direct <- list(estimate = log(0.80), se = 0.15)  # Indirect evidence via Bucher method indirect <- indirect_comparison(   effect_ab = log(0.75), se_ab = 0.12,   effect_bc = log(0.85), se_bc = 0.10,   effect_measure = "hr" )  comparison <- compare_direct_indirect(   direct_result = direct,   indirect_result = indirect,   effect_measure = "hr" ) comparison$is_consistent #> NULL

text: Generate AE summary tables clinical study reports.

title: Create Adverse Event Summary Table — create_ae_summary_table
code: create_ae_summary_table(   adae,   adsl = NULL,   type = c("overview", "soc", "soc_pt", "pt", "common", "severity", "relationship",     "sae", "discontinuation", "deaths", "comparison"),   trt_var = "TRT01P",   n_top = 15,   soc = NULL,   title = NULL,   autofit = TRUE,   ref_group = NULL,   by = "pt",   threshold = 0,   sort_by = "incidence",   conf_level = 0.95,   include_nnh = TRUE,   soc_order = NULL,   severity_levels = c("MILD", "MODERATE", "SEVERE") )

title: Create Adverse Event Summary Table — create_ae_summary_table
text: adae ADAE data frame (ADaM Adverse Events dataset) adsl ADSL data frame (optional, required table types like "deaths", "comparison", denominator calculation) type Character string specifying table type: "overview" - Summary TEAEs, related AEs, SAEs, discontinuations "soc" - AEs System Organ Class "soc_pt" - AEs SOC Preferred Term (hierarchical) "pt" - AEs Preferred Term "common" - frequently reported AEs "severity" - AEs maximum severity "relationship" - AEs relationship study drug "sae" - Serious Adverse Events "discontinuation" - AEs leading discontinuation "deaths" - Deaths summary (requires adsl) "comparison" - AE comparison RD/RR (requires adsl) trt_var Treatment variable name (default: "TRT01P") n_top type="common", number top PTs show (default: 15) soc type="pt", filter specific SOC (optional) title Table title (auto-generated NULL) autofit Logical, whether autofit column widths (default: TRUE) ref_group type="comparison", reference group comparisons type="comparison", grouping level: "soc", "pt", "overall" threshold type="comparison", minimum incidence pct (default: 0) sort_by type="comparison", sort "rd", "rr", "incidence" conf_level type="comparison", confidence level (default: 0.95) include_nnh type="comparison", include NNH column (default: TRUE) soc_order type="soc" type="soc_pt", custom ordering SOCs (character vector). NULL, SOCs sorted alphabetically (default: NULL) severity_levels type="severity", severity levels ordering (character vector). Default: c("MILD", "MODERATE", "SEVERE")

title: Create Adverse Event Summary Table — create_ae_summary_table
text: ClinicalTable object

title: Create Adverse Event Summary Table — create_ae_summary_table
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # AE Overview overview <- create_ae_summary_table(adae, adsl, type = "overview")  # SOC table soc_table <- create_ae_summary_table(adae, adsl, type = "soc")  # SOC/PT hierarchical table soc_pt <- create_ae_summary_table(adae, adsl, type = "soc_pt")  # Most common AEs (top 20) common <- create_ae_summary_table(adae, adsl, type = "common", n_top = 20)  # SAE table sae <- create_ae_summary_table(adae, adsl, type = "sae")  # AE comparison with risk differences comparison <- create_ae_summary_table(   adae, adsl,   type = "comparison",   ref_group = "Placebo",   by = "pt",   threshold = 5 )  # SOC table with custom ordering soc_ordered <- create_ae_summary_table(   adae, adsl,   type = "soc",   soc_order = c(     "Infections",     "Nervous system disorders",     "Gastrointestinal disorders"   ) ) } # }

"CNSR", inverted automatically. title: Create Funnel Plot for Publication Bias Assessment — create_funnel_plot

Plot title. Default: "Funnel Plot" xlab Character. X-axis label. Default: based effect_measure ylab Character. Y-axis label. Default: "Standard Error" contour_levels Numeric vector. Contour p-value levels. Default: c(0.1, 0.05, 0.01) base_size Numeric. Base font size. Default: 11

title: Create Funnel Plot for Publication Bias Assessment — create_funnel_plot
code: # Funnel plot for publication bias assessment yi <- log(c(0.75, 0.82, 0.68, 0.91, 0.77)) sei <- c(0.12, 0.15, 0.18, 0.14, 0.11) meta_res <- meta_analysis(yi = yi, sei = sei, effect_measure = "hr") plot <- create_funnel_plot(meta_res, title = "Funnel Plot") plot@type #> [1] "funnel"

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Plot — create_km_plot
text: Kaplan-Meier plot using ggplot2 survival.

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Plot — create_km_plot
code: create_km_plot(   data,   time_var = "AVAL",   event_var = "CNSR",   trt_var = "TRT01P",   title = "Kaplan-Meier Plot",   xlab = "Time",   ylab = "Survival Probability",   risk_table = FALSE,   show_median = FALSE,   show_ci = FALSE,   show_censor = TRUE,   landmarks = NULL,   xlim = NULL,   palette = NULL,   conf_level = 0.95,   base_size = 11,   type = c("km", "loglog") )

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Plot — create_km_plot
text: data ADaMData object data frame containing survival data time_var Time variable name (default: "AVAL") event_var Event variable name. "CNSR" (ADaM censoring flag), automatically inverted (0=event becomes 1=event). Otherwise expects 1=event, 0=censor. Default: "CNSR" trt_var Treatment variable name (default: "TRT01P") title Plot title xlab X-axis label ylab Y-axis label risk_table Logical, include risk table . Requires patchwork. show_median Logical, add horizontal/vertical lines median survival time (default: FALSE) show_ci Logical, show confidence bands around survival curves (default: FALSE) show_censor Logical, show censoring marks crosses (default: TRUE) landmarks Numeric vector timepoints highlight vertical lines (e.g., c(12, 24) 12 24 months). NULL none. xlim Optional x-axis limits c(min, max) palette Optional color palette treatment groups. Can character vector colors, NULL use getOption("pharmhand.palette"). Defaults CVD-friendly "Okabe-Ito (reordered)" palette (orange, sky blue first two arms). built-options: "Okabe-Ito", "R4", "Tableau 10", "Alphabet", etc. (see grDevices::palette.pals()). conf_level Confidence level CI bands (default: 0.95) base_size Base font size plot text elements (default: 11). Also used risk table text. type Character. Plot type: "km" Kaplan-Meier "loglog" log(-log(S(t))) vs log(t). "loglog", median lines, CI bands, risk tables, landmarks intentionally omitted keep diagnostic scale uncluttered; censor marks supported via show_censor.

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Plot — create_km_plot
text: ClinicalPlot object

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Plot — create_km_plot
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic KM plot km <- create_km_plot(   data = adtte,   time_var = "AVAL",   event_var = "CNSR",   title = "Overall Survival" )  # With median lines and CI bands km <- create_km_plot(   data = adtte,   show_median = TRUE,   show_ci = TRUE,   risk_table = TRUE ) } # }

title: Create Log-Log Survival Plot — create_loglog_plot
text: Creates log(-log(survival)) vs log(time) plot visual assessment proportional hazards assumption. Parallel curves indicate PH assumption likely satisfied.

title: Create Log-Log Survival Plot — create_loglog_plot
code: create_loglog_plot(   data,   time_var,   event_var,   trt_var,   title = "Log-Log Survival Plot",   xlab = "Log(Time)",   ylab = "Log(-Log(Survival))",   show_censor = TRUE,   colors = NULL,   base_size = 11,   conf_level = 0.95 )

title: Create Log-Log Survival Plot — create_loglog_plot
text: data ADaMData object data frame time--event data time_var Character. Name time variable event_var Character. Name event variable (1=event, 0=censor). "CNSR" (ADaM censoring flag), inverted (0=event becomes 1). trt_var Character. Name treatment variable title Character. Plot title (default: "Log-Log Survival Plot") xlab Character. X-axis label (default: "Log(Time)") ylab Character. Y-axis label (default: "Log(-Log(Survival))") show_censor Logical, show censoring marks crosses (default: TRUE). colors Named character vector colors treatment group. NULL, uses getOption("pharmhand.palette") default palette. base_size Base font size plot text elements (default: 11). conf_level Confidence level survival fit (default: 0.95)

title: Create Log-Log Survival Plot — create_loglog_plot
text: ClinicalPlot object containing ggplot2 log-log survival plot

title: Create Log-Log Survival Plot — create_loglog_plot
text: Cox proportional hazards assumption, log-log transformed survival curves approximately parallel. Crossing diverging curves suggest PH assumption may violated. complementary visual diagnostic statistical test provided test_ph_assumption(). Censor marks supported; median lines, CI bands, risk tables, landmarks intentionally omitted keep diagnostic scale uncluttered.

title: Create Log-Log Survival Plot — create_loglog_plot
text: IQWiG Methods v8.0, Section 10.3.12, p. 235-237.

title: Create Log-Log Survival Plot — create_loglog_plot

title: Create Love Plot for SMD Visualization — create_love_plot

code: create_love_plot(   balance_assessment,   threshold = 0.1,   show_ci = TRUE,   title = "Standardized Mean Differences",   xlab = "Standardized Mean Difference",   color_by_type = TRUE,   sort_by = c("abs_smd", "smd", "name", "none"),   colors = NULL,   point_size = 3,   base_size = 11 )

title: Create Love Plot for SMD Visualization — create_love_plot
text: balance_assessment BalanceAssessment object assess_baseline_balance(), data frame columns variable, smd, optionally ci_lower, ci_upper, var_type. threshold Numeric. SMD threshold reference lines (default: 0.1). Vertical lines drawn +/- threshold. balance_assessment BalanceAssessment object, stored threshold used regardless parameter. show_ci Logical. Show confidence intervals error bars (default: TRUE). title Character. Plot title (default: "Standardized Mean Differences"). xlab Character. X-axis label (default: "Standardized Mean Difference"). color_by_type Logical. Color points variable type (continuous vs categorical) available (default: TRUE). sort_by Character. sort variables: "abs_smd" (default), "smd", "name", "none". colors Named character vector colors "continuous", "categorical", "threshold" elements. NULL uses defaults. point_size Numeric. Size points (default: 3). base_size Numeric. Base font size (default: 11).

title: Create Love Plot for SMD Visualization — create_love_plot
text: ClinicalPlot object containing ggplot2 Love plot.

title: Create Love Plot for SMD Visualization — create_love_plot
text: Love plot displays baseline covariate y-axis SMD x-axis. Vertical reference lines +/- threshold help identify imbalanced covariates. Points falling outside threshold lines indicate potential baseline imbalance may require adjustment analysis.

title: Create Love Plot for SMD Visualization — create_love_plot
text: Love, T. E. (2004). Demonstrating balance groups observational studies. Presentation Cleveland Chapter American Statistical Association.

title: Create Love Plot for SMD Visualization — create_love_plot
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # From BalanceAssessment object balance <- assess_baseline_balance(   data = adsl,   trt_var = "TRT01P",   continuous_vars = c("AGE", "WEIGHT"),   categorical_vars = c("SEX", "RACE") ) love_plot <- create_love_plot(balance)  # From data frame smd_data <- data.frame(   variable = c("Age", "Sex", "Weight"),   smd = c(0.05, -0.12, 0.08),   ci_lower = c(-0.02, -0.20, 0.01),   ci_upper = c(0.12, -0.04, 0.15) ) create_love_plot(smd_data, threshold = 0.1) } # }

title: Create Mean Plot with Confidence Intervals Over Time — create_mean_plot
text: data Data frame containing data x_var Character. Variable x-axis (visit time) y_var Character. Variable y-axis (value) group_var Character. Grouping variable (e.g., treatment). Default: NULL ci_level Numeric. Confidence level intervals. Default: 0.95 show_points Logical. Show individual data points. Default: FALSE show_n Logical. Show sample size point. Default: TRUE title Character. Plot title. Default: NULL x_label Character. X-axis label. Default: NULL (uses x_var) y_label Character. Y-axis label. Default: NULL (uses y_var) palette Character vector. Colors groups. Default: NULL (uses default) base_size Numeric. Base font size. Default: 11 line_size Numeric. Line width. Default: 1 point_size Numeric. Point size means. Default: 3 dodge_width Numeric. Horizontal dodge overlapping points. Default: 0.2 error_bar_width Numeric. Width error bar caps. Default: 0.1

title: Create Subgroup Analysis Table — create_subgroup_table
code: create_subgroup_table(   data,   subgroups,   min_subgroup_size = 20,   endpoint_type = c("tte", "binary"),   time_var = "AVAL",   event_var = "CNSR",   response_var = "AVALC",   response_values = c("CR", "PR"),   trt_var = "TRT01P",   ref_group = NULL,   conf_level = 0.95,   show_interaction = TRUE,   adjust_method = c("none", "holm", "hochberg", "hommel", "bonferroni", "BH", "fdr",     "BY"),   title = "Subgroup Analysis",   autofit = TRUE )

title: Create Subgroup Analysis Table — create_subgroup_table
text: data ADaMData object data frame subgroups Named list mapping variable names display labels, e.g., list(AGEGR1 = "Age Group", SEX = "Sex", RACE = "Race") min_subgroup_size Numeric. Minimum subgroup size required warnings issued. Use NULL disable warnings. Default 20. endpoint_type "tte" time--event (HR) "binary" binary outcomes () time_var Time variable TTE endpoints (default: "AVAL") event_var Event variable TTE endpoints. "CNSR", inverted automatically. Default: "CNSR" response_var Response variable binary endpoints (default: "AVALC") response_values Values indicating response binary endpoints (default: c("CR", "PR")) trt_var Treatment variable name (default: "TRT01P") ref_group Reference treatment group. NULL, uses first level. conf_level Confidence level (default: 0.95) show_interaction Logical, calculate show interaction p-values (default: TRUE) adjust_method Character. Method adjusting interaction p-values multiple comparisons. One : "none" (default): adjustment "holm": Holm-Bonferroni step-(recommended FWER control) "hochberg": Hochberg step-(controls FWER) "hommel": Hommel's method (closed testing procedure, good correlated tests) "bonferroni": Bonferroni correction (conservative) "BH" "fdr": Benjamini-Hochberg (controls FDR) "": Benjamini-Yekutieli (controls FDR dependency) See adjust_pvalues details. title Table title autofit Logical, whether autofit column widths (default: TRUE)

title: Create Time-to-Deterioration Analysis — create_ttd_analysis
text: Performs time--deterioration (TTD) analysis PRO endpoints. Deterioration defined decrease baseline exceeding MCID.

title: Create Time-to-Deterioration Analysis — create_ttd_analysis
code: create_ttd_analysis(   data,   subject_var = "USUBJID",   trt_var = "TRT01P",   param_var = "PARAMCD",   paramcd = NULL,   value_var = "AVAL",   base_var = "BASE",   chg_var = "CHG",   time_var = "ADY",   visit_var = "AVISITN",   threshold,   direction = c("decrease", "increase"),   definition = c("first", "confirmed"),   confirmation_visits = 1,   censor_at = NULL )

title: Create Time-to-Deterioration Analysis — create_ttd_analysis
text: data Data frame longitudinal PRO data subject_var Character. Subject ID variable. Default: "USUBJID" trt_var Character. Treatment variable. Default: "TRT01P" param_var Character. Parameter variable. Default: "PARAMCD" paramcd Character. Parameter code analyze. Default: NULL (uses first) value_var Character. Value variable. Default: "AVAL" base_var Character. Baseline value variable. Default: "BASE" chg_var Character. Change baseline variable. Default: "CHG" time_var Character. Time/day variable. Default: "ADY" visit_var Character. Visit number variable. Default: "AVISITN" threshold Numeric. MCID threshold deterioration (positive = improvement) direction Character. "decrease" lower worse, "increase" higher worse definition Character. "first" "confirmed" deterioration. Default: "first" confirmation_visits Integer. Visits confirm (definition="confirmed") censor_at Numeric. Time censor event. Default: max time data

title: Create Time-to-Deterioration Analysis — create_ttd_analysis
text: list components: ttd_data Prepared time--deterioration data frame km_fit Kaplan-Meier fit object survfit summary_table Summary statistics treatment group threshold MCID threshold used direction Direction deterioration definition Deterioration definition used n_subjects Total number subjects n_events Total number deterioration events

title: Create Time-to-Deterioration Analysis — create_ttd_analysis
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create time-to-deterioration analysis ttd <- create_ttd_analysis(   data = pro_data,   threshold = 5,   direction = "decrease" )  # Access summary table ttd$summary_table } # }

title: Create Time-to-Event Summary Table — create_tte_summary_table
text: Generates standard TTE summary table median survival, confidence intervals, hazard ratios, optional landmark estimates efficacy endpoints like OS, PFS, EFS.

title: Create Time-to-Event Summary Table — create_tte_summary_table
code: create_tte_summary_table(   data,   time_var = "AVAL",   event_var = "CNSR",   trt_var = "TRT01P",   ref_group = NULL,   conf_level = 0.95,   check_ph = TRUE,   landmarks = NULL,   time_unit = "months",   title = "Time-to-Event Summary",   autofit = TRUE )

title: Create Time-to-Event Summary Table — create_tte_summary_table
text: data ADaMData object data frame containing TTE data time_var Time variable name (default: "AVAL") event_var Event indicator variable. "CNSR" (ADaM censoring flag), automatically inverted (0=event becomes 1=event). Otherwise expects 1=event, 0=censor. Default: "CNSR" trt_var Treatment variable name (default: "TRT01P") ref_group Reference group HR calculation. NULL, uses first level treatment variable. conf_level Confidence level intervals (default: 0.95) check_ph Logical. Whether test proportional hazards assumption warn violations (default: TRUE) landmarks Numeric vector timepoints landmark survival estimates (e.g., c(12, 24) 12 24 month rates). NULL none. time_unit Character string time unit display (default: "months") title Table title autofit Logical, whether autofit column widths (default: TRUE)

title: Create Time-to-Event Summary Table — create_tte_summary_table

title: Indirect Treatment Comparison (Bucher Method) — indirect_comparison
text: Calculates indirect treatment effect comparing vs C common comparator B using Bucher method (anchored indirect comparison).

title: Indirect Treatment Comparison (Bucher Method) — indirect_comparison
code: indirect_comparison(   effect_ab,   se_ab,   effect_bc,   se_bc,   effect_measure = c("hr", "or", "rr", "rd", "md", "smd"),   conf_level = 0.95,   label_a = "A",   label_b = "B",   label_c = "C" )

title: Indirect Treatment Comparison (Bucher Method) — indirect_comparison
text: effect_ab Effect estimate vs B comparison se_ab Standard error vs B effect_bc Effect estimate B vs C comparison se_bc Standard error B vs C effect_measure Character. Effect type: "hr", "", "rr", "rd", "md", "smd" conf_level Numeric. Confidence level. Default: 0.95 label_a Character. Label treatment . Default: "" label_b Character. Label treatment B (comparator). Default: "B" label_c Character. Label treatment C. Default: "C"

title: Indirect Treatment Comparison (Bucher Method) — indirect_comparison
text: ComparisonResult object indirect effect estimate vs C

title: Indirect Treatment Comparison (Bucher Method) — indirect_comparison
code: # Bucher indirect comparison: Drug A vs Drug B via Placebo # Drug A vs Placebo: HR = 0.75 # Drug B vs Placebo: HR = 0.85 result <- indirect_comparison(   effect_ab = log(0.75),   se_ab = 0.12,   effect_bc = log(0.85),   se_bc = 0.10,   effect_measure = "hr",   label_a = "Drug A",   label_b = "Placebo",   label_c = "Drug B" ) result@estimate #> [1] 0.8823529 result@ci #> [1] 0.6496514 1.1984068

text: data Data frame study-level summary statistics StudySet object yi Numeric vector effect estimates (log scale ratios) sei Numeric vector standard errors ni Numeric vector sample sizes (optional) study_labels Character vector study names effect_measure Character. Type effect: "hr", "", "rr", "rd", "md", "smd" model Character. "fixed" "random". Default: "random" method Character. Estimation method random effects: "DL" (DerSimonian-Laird), "REML", "PM" (Paule-Mandel). Default: "REML" knapp_hartung Logical. Apply Knapp-Hartung adjustment. Default: TRUE conf_level Numeric. Confidence level. Default: 0.95 prediction Logical. Calculate prediction interval. Default: TRUE

title: Conducts network meta-analysis (NMA) to compare multiple treatments simultaneously using direct and indirect evidence. — network_meta
text: data Data frame study-level data. Required columns: study (study identifier), treat1 (treatment 1), treat2 (treatment 2), effect (effect estimate), se (standard error) study_var Character. Study identifier column. Default: "study" treat1_var Character. Treatment 1 column. Default: "treat1" treat2_var Character. Treatment 2 column. Default: "treat2" effect_var Character. Effect estimate column. Default: "effect" se_var Character. Standard error column. Default: "se" reference Character. Reference treatment. Default: first alphabetically effect_measure Character. Effect type: "hr", "", "rr", "rd", "md", "smd" model Character. "fixed" "random". Default: "random" method Character. NMA method: "bucher" (simple), "graph" (yet implemented, defaults bucher) conf_level Numeric. Confidence level. Default: 0.95

text: List relative effects, rankings, network structure

title: Conducts network meta-analysis (NMA) to compare multiple treatments simultaneously using direct and indirect evidence. — network_meta
text: ratio measures ("hr", "", "rr"), effect estimates must log scale. difference measures ("rd", "md", "smd"), effect estimates must raw scale.

title: Conducts network meta-analysis (NMA) to compare multiple treatments simultaneously using direct and indirect evidence. — network_meta
code: # Network meta-analysis of 4 studies nma_data <- data.frame(   study = c("S1", "S2", "S3", "S4"),   treat1 = c("A", "B", "A", "B"),   treat2 = c("B", "C", "C", "D"),   effect = log(c(0.75, 0.90, 0.80, 0.85)),   se = c(0.12, 0.15, 0.18, 0.14) ) result <- network_meta(nma_data, effect_measure = "hr") result@comparisons #>   treatment vs estimate  ci_lower  ci_upper        se n_studies  evidence rank #> 1         A  A   1.0000 1.0000000 1.0000000 0.0000000        NA reference   NA #> B         B  A   0.7500 0.5928121 0.9488672 0.1200000         1    direct    2 #> C         C  A   0.8000 0.5621778 1.1384298 0.1800000         1    direct    3 #> D         D  A   0.6375 0.4441466 0.9150272 0.1843909         2  indirect    1 result@network$treatments #> [1] "A" "B" "C" "D"

title: Separates direct and indirect evidence for each comparison and tests for inconsistency between them. — node_splitting
text: simplified implementation. Full node-splitting requires re-running network meta-analysis excluding direct evidence comparison, computationally intensive. Consider using specialized NMA packages (e.g., gemtc, netmeta) rigorous inconsistency assessment.

title: Separates direct and indirect evidence for each comparison and tests for inconsistency between them. — node_splitting
code: # Node-splitting for inconsistency testing nma_data <- data.frame(   study = c("S1", "S2", "S3"),   treat1 = c("A", "B", "A"),   treat2 = c("B", "C", "C"),   effect = log(c(0.75, 0.90, 0.80)),   se = c(0.12, 0.15, 0.18) ) nma_result <- network_meta(nma_data, effect_measure = "hr") ns_result <- node_splitting(nma_result) ns_result$note #> [1] "Full node-splitting requires re-analysis excluding direct evidence. Results shown are simplified."

title: Non-Inferiority Test — test_non_inferiority
text: Tests non-inferiority treatment vs comparator.

title: Non-Inferiority Test — test_non_inferiority
code: test_non_inferiority(   data,   outcome_var,   trt_var,   ref_group,   ni_margin,   type = c("continuous", "binary"),   higher_better = TRUE,   conf_level = 0.975,   method = c("wilson", "wald", "exact") )

title: Non-Inferiority Test — test_non_inferiority
text: data Data frame outcome_var Character. Outcome variable name trt_var Character. Treatment variable name ref_group Character. Reference group name ni_margin Numeric. Non-inferiority margin (positive value) type Character. "continuous" "binary" higher_better Logical. TRUE higher values better (default: TRUE) conf_level Numeric. One-sided confidence level (default: 0.975, equivalent two-sided 95% CI) method Character. Method binary endpoints : "wald", "wilson", "exact" (default: "wilson"). Ignored continuous endpoints.

title: Non-Inferiority Test — test_non_inferiority
text: List : estimate: Point estimate difference (trt - ref) ci_lower: Lower bound one-sided CI ci_upper: Upper bound (may Inf one-sided) ni_margin: margin used non_inferior: Logical. TRUE non-inferiority concluded. higher_better=TRUE: ci_lower > -ni_margin. higher_better=FALSE: ci_upper < ni_margin. conclusion: Character summary method: Method used

title: Non-Inferiority Test — test_non_inferiority
text: continuous endpoints: Tests (mean_trt - mean_ref) + ni_margin > 0 binary endpoints: Tests (prop_trt - prop_ref) + ni_margin > 0 Non-inferiority concluded lower bound one-sided CI treatment difference exceeds -ni_margin. direction test depends higher_better: higher_better=TRUE (default): lower CI bound must exceed -ni_margin higher_better=FALSE: upper CI bound must ni_margin binary endpoints, Wilson method uses Newcombe-Wilson hybrid CI approach. Wald method provides simpler alternative. regulatory submissions, verify CI method aligns agency preferences.

title: Non-Inferiority Test — test_non_inferiority
text: IQWiG Methods v8.0, Section 10.3.5, p. 217-218.

title: Non-Inferiority Test — test_non_inferiority
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Non-inferiority test for continuous endpoint result <- test_non_inferiority(   data = adeff,   outcome_var = "CHG",   trt_var = "TRT01P",   ref_group = "Active Control",   ni_margin = 0.5,   type = "continuous" )  # Non-inferiority test for binary endpoint result <- test_non_inferiority(   data = adrs,   outcome_var = "AVALC",   trt_var = "TRT01P",   ref_group = "Active Control",   ni_margin = 0.10,   type = "binary" ) } # }

Event variable (required data data frame) trt_var Character. Treatment variable (required data data frame) covariates Character vector. Additional covariates include alpha Numeric. Significance level flagging violations (default: 0.05) plot Logical. Whether create diagnostic plot (default: FALSE)

title: Test Proportional Hazards Assumption — test_ph_assumption

title: Test Proportional Hazards Assumption — test_ph_assumption

title: Duval & Tweedie Trim-and-Fill Publication Bias Adjustment — trim_and_fill
code: trim_and_fill(   meta_result,   side = c("auto", "left", "right"),   estimator = c("L0", "R0", "Q0"),   maxiter = 100 )

title: Duval & Tweedie Trim-and-Fill Publication Bias Adjustment — trim_and_fill
text: meta_result MetaResult object meta_analysis() side Character. Side excess studies trimmed: "left", "right", "auto". Missing studies imputed opposite side. Default: "auto" estimator Character. Method estimate missing studies: "L0", "R0", "Q0". Default: "L0" maxiter Integer. Maximum iterations. Default: 100

title: Duval & Tweedie Trim-and-Fill Publication Bias Adjustment — trim_and_fill
text: list components: original List original estimate, confidence interval, k adjusted List adjusted estimate, confidence interval, k n_imputed Estimated number missing studies side Side studies imputed imputed_studies Data frame imputed effects estimator Estimator method used effect_measure Effect measure used interpretation Text interpretation adjustment

title: Duval & Tweedie Trim-and-Fill Publication Bias Adjustment — trim_and_fill
code: # Trim-and-fill for publication bias adjustment yi <- c(-0.5, -0.4, -0.3, -0.1, 0.0, 0.5, 0.6) sei <- c(0.1, 0.12, 0.15, 0.18, 0.2, 0.1, 0.12) meta_res <- meta_analysis(yi = yi, sei = sei, effect_measure = "md") adjusted <- trim_and_fill(meta_res) adjusted$n_imputed #> [1] 0 adjusted$interpretation #> [1] "No missing studies detected"
